feed.title: Newswise Breaking News Channel: Natural Disasters
feed.description: This breaking news channel highlights experts, research, and feature stories related to natural disasters such as earthquakes, volcanoes, floods, environmental crisis, and more

items.title: Tornado Experts at Texas Tech Available to Give Insight on Severe Weather
items.author: Texas Tech University

items.title: Monday's West Virginia earthquake rare in magnitude, likely a natural occurrence
items.author: West Virginia University

items.title: US remains stagnant in climate change vulnerability and readiness, new data show
items.author: University of Notre Dame
items.description: For the fourth year in a row, the United States has ranked 15th in the University of Notre Dame's Global Adaptation Initiative (ND-GAIN) Country Index.'
items.content: For the fourth year in a row, the United States has ranked 15th in the University of Notre Dame's Global Adaptation Initiative (ND-GAIN) Country Index.'

items.title: Predicting Hope
items.author: University of Oklahoma, Gallogly College of Engineering
items.description: The devastation of the Peruvian floods of March 2017 caused native and University of Oklahoma Electrical and Computer Engineering Assistant Professor, Salazar-Cerreno, to look for ways to apply his expertise to help improve weather decision making and warnings.'
items.content: The devastation of the Peruvian floods of March 2017 caused native and University of Oklahoma Electrical and Computer Engineering Assistant Professor, Salazar-Cerreno, to look for ways to apply his expertise to help improve weather decision making and warnings.'

items.title: Don't Panic: Lessons Learned From Hawaii False Alarm
items.author: University of Georgia
items.description: False alarm text message made residents of Hawaii check what others were doing to verify risk
items.content: False alarm text message made residents of Hawaii check what others were doing to verify risk

items.title: Kentucky Geological Survey researcher to develop landslide models, risk assessments in Eastern Kentucky
items.author: University of Kentucky
items.description: Funded by FEMA, the three-year project will allow Matt Crawford, a landslide researcher, to work with local officials in eastern Kentucky to adopt strategies for reducing landslide risks to infrastructure and improving response for landslide events.
items.content: Funded by FEMA, the three-year project will allow Matt Crawford, a landslide researcher, to work with local officials in eastern Kentucky to adopt strategies for reducing landslide risks to infrastructure and improving response for landslide events.

items.title: FSU Receives $8 Million to Revive Apalachicola Bay
items.author: Florida State University
items.description: Florida State researchers have been awarded $8 million to restore Apalachicola Bay and revive the region's imperiled oyster industry thanks to money the state recovered from the BP oil spill.
items.content: Florida State researchers have been awarded $8 million to restore Apalachicola Bay and revive the region's imperiled oyster industry thanks to money the state recovered from the BP oil spill.

items.title: 2,350-Mile Walk from Canada to Key West Spotlights How People with Disabilities are Affected by Extreme Weather
items.author: Association of Academic Physiatrists (AAP)
items.description: 'Canada to Key West,' a 2,350-mile walk to raise awareness about the impact of increasingly frequent extreme weather events will start on June 21, 2019, the day of the summer solstice.
items.content: 'Canada to Key West,' a 2,350-mile walk to raise awareness about the impact of increasingly frequent extreme weather events will start on June 21, 2019, the day of the summer solstice.

items.title: In Disasters, Twitter Influencers Get Out-Tweeted
items.author: University of Vermont
items.description: A first-of-its-kind study on Twitter use during 5 of the costliest U.S. natural disasters offers potentially life-saving insights. The research, in PLOS ONE, finds that Twitter users with small networks (100-200 followers) increase activity more than those with larger networks in these situations. It also finds that each disaster type (hurricanes, tornadoes, floods) has a unique pattern of social media use.
items.content: A first-of-its-kind study on Twitter use during 5 of the costliest U.S. natural disasters offers potentially life-saving insights. The research, in PLOS ONE, finds that Twitter users with small networks (100-200 followers) increase activity more than those with larger networks in these situations. It also finds that each disaster type (hurricanes, tornadoes, floods) has a unique pattern of social media use.

items.title: How Innovative Funding Sources Can Secure Sustainable Infrastructure for Cities
items.author: Houston Advanced Research Center (HARC)
items.description: HARC released a special report today for public and private sector leaders that addresses how to fund critical infrastructure required to maintain the safety and well-being of cities and communities. The Green Paper is entitled 'Funding Resilience in the Greater Houston Region: Synopsis from a Public-Private Sector Workshop.'
items.content: HARC released a special report today for public and private sector leaders that addresses how to fund critical infrastructure required to maintain the safety and well-being of cities and communities. The Green Paper is entitled 'Funding Resilience in the Greater Houston Region: Synopsis from a Public-Private Sector Workshop.'
